item.title: navigating SPSS data with purrr and stringr - part i
item.description: Download data for this blog There is a lot not to like about SPSS: it’s expensive, it’s proprietary, it’s not very flexible. But I have to give it credit for one thing: maintaining separate variable names and labels. In SPSS data files–which use the .sav extension–each variable has a name like an R variable. These names follow many of the same conventions of R variable names, for example, they can’t contain spaces or start with numbers.

item.title: navigating SPSS variables with purrr and stringr - part ii
item.description: Recap Last post, I wrote about how we can access SPSS variable metadata using the attributes() and attr() functions in R; in combination with purrr:map_chr() we can easily view variable labels, levels, and more. Though the sample data I’ve created only has 10 variables, often I find myself working with hundreds, and little idea how to find the precise variable names I’m looking for. I’ve found stringr:str_detect() (in conjuction with dplyr::select_if()) to be particularly powerful in this scenario.
